items.description: River Severn at the Showground and The Quarry, Shrewsbury
items.message:
River levels remain high but are continuing to fall at the Welshbridge river gauge. Flooding continues. We expect flooding to affect offices at the showground and Gravel Hill Lane.
Peaks:- Welshbridge peaked at 5.15m on Tuesday morning 22/02/22. 
We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. Our incident response staff are checking defences. 
The river level forecasts displayed on GOV.UK are the raw data output from the Forecasting System computer models. These have not had an expert Flood Forecaster adjustment applied. This will sometimes result in slightly different level forecasts between the forecast levels provided on GOV.UK and to those shown within this message.
This message will be updated by 6pm on Thursday 24/02/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Severn at Severn Ham, Tewkesbury
items.message:
River levels remain high at the Mythe Bridge river gauge as a result of recent heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding continues. We expect flooding to affect Mill Avon riverside property, minor roads at Tirely, Chaceley, Hasfield, Hawbridge, Lower Lode, Ashleworth, Deerhurst, Wainlode and Apperley. Also affected are properties and roads in and around Severn Ham, Tewkesbury. Access to Abbey Mill is compromised.
Predicted Peaks:- Upper Pound 4.2m to 4.4m on Friday morning, 25/02/2022 and Mythe 4.2m to 4.4m on Friday morning, 25/02/2022.
We expect river levels to remain high into next week. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are liaising with emergency services.  
Please avoid contact with flood water and move possessions and valuables off the ground or to safety.  
This message will be updated by 6:00pm on Thursday, 24/02/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Severn at Ironbridge and Jackfield
items.message:
River levels remain high but are slowly starting to fall at the Buildwas river gauge following recent heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding continues. We expect flooding to affect properties on Ferry Road. 

Buildwas peaked at a level of 6.60m early Wednesday morning, 23/02/22.

We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are checking defences. Please avoid using low lying roads and footpaths near local watercourses and avoid contact with flood water.

This message will be updated by 7pm on Thursday 24/02/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Severn at Court Meadow, Kempsey and Callow End
items.message:
The river level has peaked at the Kempsey Yacht Club gauge but remains high as a result of recent heavy rain. Flooding of property, roads and farmland continues. We expect flooding to affect Court Meadow Caravan Park and could affect properties at Lower Ferry Lane, Callow End. 
The Kempsey Yacht Club gauge peaked at 7.05m on Wednesday evening, 23/02/22.   
We expect river levels to remain high this week. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are liaising with emergency services.  
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated by 6:00pm on Thursday, 24/02/22, or as the situation changes.

Bridgnorth peaked at a level of 5.10m at 5.45am on Wednesday 23/02/22.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking defences.  
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid contact with flood water.
This message will be updated by 6pm on Thursday 24/02/22, or as the situation changes.

The flood warning remains in force for the River Ouse at Naburn. The River Ouse has peaked at a level of 4.58m. The river levels are now beginning to fall slowly. Flooding is expected to affect locations near the River Ouse, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around Naburn Lock Buildings and Lock Cottages. Flooding of properties, gardens, roads and paths is expected. Consider putting your flood plan into action. You should avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. The Foss Barrier is operating, and our field teams have closed riverside floodgates. Visit the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast and up to date river levels. This message will be updated by 9AM on Thursday 24/02/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Ouse at York - riverside properties
items.message: The flood warning remains in force for the River Ouse at York, Riverside Properties. The River Ouse has peaked at a level of 4.58m on Tuesday 22/02/22. The river levels are now beginning to fall slowly. Flooding remains a risk near the River Ouse, including properties on King's Staith in York, and riverside areas through York from Lendal Bridge to Millennium Bridge. Flooding of properties, gardens, roads and paths is expected. Consider putting your flood plan into action. You should avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. The Foss Barrier is operating, and our field teams have closed riverside floodgates. Visit the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast and up to date river levels. This message will be updated by 9AM on Thursday 24/02/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Ouse at York - St George's Field and Queen's Staith
items.message: The flood warning remains in force for the River Ouse at York - St George's Field and Queen's Staith. The River Ouse has peaked at a level of 4.58m on Tuesday 22/02/22. The river levels are now beginning to fall slowly. Flooding remains a risk near the River Ouse, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around properties along Queen's Staith, on South Esplanade, Friars Terrace and Tower Place. St George's Field car park and Rowntree Park also. Flooding of properties, gardens, roads and paths is expected. The Foss Barrier is operating, and our field teams have closed riverside floodgates. Consider putting your flood plan into action. You should avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. Visit the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast and up to date river levels. This message will be updated by 9AM on Thursday 24/02/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water
items.message: Lake and river levels remain high, but are now receding on the Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water due to recent heavy rainfall.  Flooding of low lying land will continue to affect areas bordering the shores of Derwent Water and the lake frontage of the Keswick Camping and Caravan Club Site over the next few days. We are continuing to monitor the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near Derwentwater and local watercourses which may be flooded and avoid driving through floodwater. This message will be updated tomorrow, 25/02/2022, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Brathay, River Rothay, River Winster

items.message: River and lake levels remain high, but are now receding on Windermere and on the Rivers Brathay, Rothay and Winster due to recent heavy rainfall. Flooding of low lying land will continue to affect areas along the Rivers Brathay, Rothay and Winster and other watercourses, from Grasmere to Grange-over-Sands including low lying areas around Ambleside, Skelwith Bridge, Windermere, Hawkshead, Newby Bridge, Backbarrow, Cark and Cartmel. We are continuing to monitor the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and avoid driving through flood water. This message will be updated tomorrow 25/02/2022 or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high but are now falling slowly at the Cae Howel & Llanymynech gauges following recent heavy rainfall. Flooding continues. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from the Welsh border at Llawnt to Shrawardine near Shrewsbury. Other locations that may be affected include Llanymynech, Maesbrook and Melverley.
Peaks:- Llanymynech peaked at 5.3m on Sunday night, 20/02/22. The current level at the Cae Howel gauge is 5.57m at 4pm on Wednesday 23/02/22. 
We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are checking defences. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and avoid contact with flood water. 
This message will be updated by 5pm on Thursday 24/02/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Middle River Mersey catchment including areas near Bramhall, Stockport, Sale, Altrincham and Urmston

floodArea.county: Cheshire East, Manchester, Salford, Stockport, Tameside, Trafford, Warrington

items.message: River levels are continuing to fall on the River Mersey following the weekend’s heavy rainfall and levels within the flood storage areas at Sale and Didsbury are being lowered.  However, flood water remains on the flood plain around East Didsbury, West Didsbury and Northenden, particularly around Stenner Lane where the flood gates are still closed.  Please do not attempt to drive or walk through flood water and please be aware of your surroundings. We will continue to monitor the situation. This message will be updated tomorrow 24/02/2022, or as the situation changes.

River levels are falling, but remain high at the Hay on Wye, Bredwardine, Belmont, Old Wye Bridge, Mordiford & Ross on Wye river gauges as a result of heavy rainfall. We expect flooding to affect low lying land & roads along the River Wye from Hay on Wye to Ross on Wye.
Other locations that may be affected include the main A438 between Letton & Willersey, Byford, Bredwardine, Hereford, the North River bank footpath Hereford & King Georges playing fields. Wilton lane may flood up to the Fishermans Reach junction, Ross.  
Peaks:- Hay on Wye peaked at 4.6m Monday morning 21/02/22, Bredwardine at 6.55m Monday morning 21/02/22, Belmont at 6.08m Monday evening 21/02/22, Old Wye Bridge at 5.38m on Monday evening 21/02/22, Mordiford at 5.13m Monday evening 21/02/22 and Ross on Wye 4.71m on Tuesday morning 22/02/22. 
We expect river levels to remain high for the next few days. We are monitoring the situation. Avoid contact with flood water. 
This message will be updated by 5pm on Thursday 24/02/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal River Ouse from Naburn Lock to Selby
items.message: Levels on the River Ouse are continuing to fall slowly. However, flooding continues to affect locations near the River Ouse and several flood warnings remain in force, with low lying land most affected, particularly around riverside footpaths and low lying land in Acaster Malbis, Acaster Selby and Naburn Lock, particularly around high tide times. We are monitoring river levels closely and with no further significant rainfall expected over the coming days, we expect levels to continue to fall slowly towards normal. However, water may remain on low lying land, Ings and washlands for several days.  Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. Plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 10PM on Thursday 24/02/2022, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Ouse, Burdyke, Holgate Beck, Blue Beck, River Foss, The Fleet

items.message: Levels on the River Ouse are continuing to fall slowly. However, flooding continues to affect locations near the River Ouse and several flood warnings remain in force, with low lying land most affected, particularly around riverside footpaths and low lying land in York, and to the south as far as Naburn Lock, including Kings Staith, Queens Staith, and South Esplanade. The Foss Barrier in York is operating, and our field teams have closed riverside floodgates. Clifton Ings is also in operation. No further significant rainfall is expected over the next few days, so we expect the levels to continue to fall towards normal. This message will be updated  by 10PM on Thursday 24/02/2022, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high at all river gauges following recent heavy rainfall. Flooding continues. Flooding is affecting low lying land & roads adjacent the river from Shrewsbury to Upper Arley. Locations that may be affected are Hayes Basin, White Abbey, Leighton, Coalbrookdale, Ironbridge, Bridgnorth & Gravel Hill Lane, Shrewsbury.
Crew Green peaked at 6.63m & Montford peaked at 7.02m Monday evening 21/02/22; Welshbridge peaked at 5.15m Tuesday morning 22/02/22.  Buildwas peaked at 6.6m &  Bridgnorth peaked at 5.1m Wednesday morning 23/02/22.
We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. Our incident response staff are checking defences. The river level forecasts displayed on GOV.UK are the raw data output from the Forecasting System computer models. These have not had an expert Flood Forecaster adjustment applied. This will sometimes result in slightly different level forecasts between levels provided on GOV.UK and those shown in this message.
This message will be updated by 7pm 24/02/22 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper Avon River Swift and Clay Coton Brook
items.message: River levels are forecast to rise at the Lilbourne and Clay Coton river gauges as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible later this morning and afternoon. Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads adjacent to River Avon between Stanford and Rugby, River Swift between Cosford and Rugby and Clay Coton Brook between Yelvertoft and Lilbourne. Further light rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated in 8 hours, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high at the Willington and Shardlow river gauges as a result of recent heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue. Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Willington, Barrow upon Trent, Swarkestone, Bargate Lane, and the access roads to Willington Meadows, the Twyford Village access road, Church Lane at Barrow, and Ingleby Lane. We expect river levels to remain high for the next few days. Further light rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and avoid contact with flood water. This message will be updated this evening, 24/02/22, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high but are now falling slowly at the Ross-On-Wye and Lydbrook river gauges following heavy rainfall.  Flooding continues.  Flooding is affecting low lying land and roads along the River Wye.
Ross on Wye peaked at 4.71m on Tuesday morning, 22/02/22.   
We expect river levels to remain high for several days.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking defences and liaising with emergency services.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated by 7pm on Thursday 24/02/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Dee catchment in England from Whitchurch to Chester

floodArea.county: Cheshire West and Chester, Flintshire, Shropshire, Wrexham

items.message: River levels on the River Dee  are continuing to fall slowly. They are expected to remain above Flood Alert levels for several more days. Flooding remains possible at low lying land and roads around the River Dee at Shocklach, Farndon, Handley, Lower Kinnerton, Chester and Puddington. Townfield Lane at Farndon will continue to be cut off for the next few days. No further significant rainfall is forecast. We will continue to monitor levels closely. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 12:00 noon on 24/02/2022, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high at the Lugwardine river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. River levels are falling at the Butts Bridge and Ford Bridge river gauges.  Flooding continues. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the River Lugg south of Leominster from Stoke Prior to Mordiford. Other locations that may be affected include Bodenham, Lugwardine and Hampton Bishop. 
We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid contact with flood water. 
This message will be updated by 5pm on Thursday 24/02/22, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Shropshire, Staffordshire, Telford and Wrekin, Wrexham

items.message:
River levels remain high but are now falling slowly at the Yeaton, Rodington and Tern - Walcot river gauges as a result of heavy rainfall. Flooding continues. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from Wolverley to Newport. Other locations that may be affected include Market Drayton, Wem and Rodington. 
We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid contact with flood water. 
This message will be updated by 6pm on Thursday 24/02/22, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Teme, River Onny, River Corve

items.message:
River levels remain high but are now falling slowly at the Leintwardine, Onibury & Ludlow (Corve) river gauges as a result of heavy rainfall. Flooding continues. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the River Teme, River Onny and River Corve and their tributaries. Locations that may be affected include Bishops Castle, Church Stretton, Knighton and Ludlow. 
Peak levels occurred at Leintwardine, Onibury & Ludlow Corve river gauges on Monday morning 21/02/22.
We expect river levels to remain high until Thursday 24/02/22.  We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid contact with flood water. 
This message will be updated by 7pm on Thursday 24/02/22 or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high but steady at the Pillings Lock river gauge as a result of recent rainfall. Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Slash Lane at Sileby and the Mountsorrel to Sileby road. Further light rainfall is forecast over the next few days. We expect river levels to remain high for the rest of the day, and into tomorrow, 25/2/22. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated this evening, 24/02/22, or as the situation changes

Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels are high on the River Thame following recent rainfall. Therefore, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue today, 24/02/2022, especially around the Thame, Stadhampton and Dorchester areas. 
Further rain is forecast through this morning (24/02/2022) with the potential to be heavy at times. This is forecast to clear through Thursday with drier conditions from Friday. River levels are still high in the Thame area but are continuing to fall slowly. Levels are still high and rising slowly in Stadhampton and Dorchester as water moves downstream but should start to stabilise later today. We expect river levels to remain high and out of banks over the coming days. 
Our incident response staff have been in the area clearing trash screens. Please refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 
This message will be updated this evening, 24/02/2022, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high at the Mythe Bridge river gauge as a result of recent heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue. We expect flooding to be affecting low lying land and roads adjacent to the River Severn from Tewkesbury to Gloucester. Locations that may be affected include Apperley and Maisemore. 
As a result of recent heavy rainfall, we expect river levels to remain high this week.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. 

This message will be updated by 6:00pm on Thursday, 24/02/22, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high and steady at the Ashford river gauge as a result of recent heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue. Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Ashford and Bakewell areas. Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours. We expect river levels to remain high over the next days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated in 12 hours, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Severn estuary from Gloucester to Sharpness
items.message:
High tides combined with high fluvial levels will be at their highest, Thursday, 24/02/22 between 2am and 4am. 
Flooding to roads and farmland is expected at these times, however conditions may apply two to four hours either side of the high tide. Flooding may affect low lying land and roads adjacent the Severn Estuary from Sandhurst to Chepstow and Sharpness. High tides may also affect watercourses draining into the Severn Estuary. 
Predicted peaks:- Gloucester 3.6m to 3.8m and Sandhurst 3.7m to 4.1m on Thursday 24/02/22;
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. 
This message will be updated by 10am on Thursday, 24/02/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Ray and its tributaries from Shipton Lee to and including Islip

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Ray, Wootten Brook, Doddershall Brook, Tetchwick Brook, Lugershall Brook, Murswell Hill Brook, Cutters Brook, Piddington Brook, Blackthorn Brook, Panshill Brook, Studley Wood Brook, Beckley Brook, Oddington Brook, Gallos Brook, Chipping Farm Stream

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels are high on the River Ray following recent rainfall. Flooding of low lying roads and farmland is expected to continue today, 24/02/2022, in the areas around Lower Arncott and Islip.
Further rain is forecast this morning (24/02/2022) with the potential to be heavy at times. This is forecast to clear through Thursday with drier conditions from Friday. Levels are still falling at Lower Arncott and should continue to fall today. Levels are forecast to continue to rise slowly in Islip before stabilising later today.  We expect river levels will remain high and out of banks over the next few days.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff will be in the area clearing trash screens.
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels.
This message will be updated this evening, 24/02/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Trent from Cromwell Weir to Gainsborough
items.message: River levels remain high at the Torksey river gauge as a result of high spring tides coinciding with high river levels. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue. The areas most at risk are Church Laneham to Rampton Road. Further light rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated this evening, 24/02/2022, or as the situation changes.

River levels continue to rise as a result of recent rainfall. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from Highley to Tewkesbury. Locations that may be affected include Stourport, Holt Fleet, Worcester, Kempsey, Severn Stoke, Upton upon Severn, South Quay, Diglis Parade and Hylton Road towpath. Flooding from drains may also be affecting Worcester racecourse and County cricket ground. 
As a result of recent heavy rainfall, we expect river levels to remain high this week.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our staff are checking defences. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and roads near local rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated by 6:00pm on Thursday, 24/02/22, or as the situation changes.

River levels continue to rise at the Kempsey Yacht Club river gauge as a result of recent rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and Squires walk in the area of the Hatfield Brook Kempsey. Kempsey Flood Alleviation scheme is operational. 
As a result of recent heavy rainfall, we expect river levels to remain high this week.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking defences.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated by 6:00pm on Thursday, 24/02/22, or as the situation changes.

River levels are high but steady at the Kempsey Yacht Club river gauge following recent heavy rainfall. River levels are now falling at the Ludlow, Tenbury, Knightsford Bridge and Bransford river gauges. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the River Teme from Ludlow to Bransford. Locations that may be affected include Tenbury Wells and Knightwick.  
Knightsford Bridge peaked at 5.30m early Tuesday morning, 22/02/22, and Bransford peaked at 5.14m on Tuesday morning 22/02/22.
We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. 
This message will be updated by 7pm on Thursday 24/02/22, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high at the Bredon river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected.

We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the River Avon from Abbotts Salford to Tewkesbury. Other locations that may be affected include Offenham, Evesham, Twyning. 

Bredon river gauge peaked at 2.84m on Tuesday 22 February.
As a result of recent heavy rainfall, we expect river levels to remain high this week.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are liaising with emergency services.  
Please avoid contact with flood water and move possessions and valuables off the ground or to safety.  

This message will be updated by 6:00pm on Thursday, 24/02/22, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high but slowly falling at the Church Wilne river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, the risk of flooding remains. Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Church Wilne, Draycott, and Wilne Lane between Draycott and Sawley. Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours. We expect river levels to remain high through today. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated in 12 hours, or as the situation changes.

River levels are steady but high at the Brimscombe river gauge as a result of recent heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of property, roads and farmland is expected to continue.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from Elmore to Sharpness. Other locations that may be affected include Chalford, Leonard Stanley and Cambridge.   
As a result of recent heavy rainfall, we expect river levels to remain high this week.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and avoid contact with flood water.  
This message will be updated by 6:00pm on Thursday, 24/02/22, or as the situation changes.

items.message: Levels on the Lower River Derwent are continuing to fall slowly. However, flooding continues to affect locations near the River Derwent, with riverside footpaths and low lying land particularly affected around Elvington. We are monitoring river levels closely and with no further significant rainfall expected over the coming days, we expect levels to continue to slowly fall towards normal. However, water may remain on low lying land, Ings and washlands for several days.  Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. Plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 10PM on Thursday 24/02/2022, or as the situation changes.

Levels on the Tidal River Wharfe are continuing to fall slowly. However, flooding continues to affect locations near the River Wharfe, with riverside footpaths and low lying land particularly affected around high tide times. We are monitoring river levels closely and with no further significant rainfall expected over the coming  days, we expect levels to continue to fall slowly towards normal. However, water may remain on low lying land, Ings and washlands for several days.  Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. Plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 10PM on Thursday 24/02/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Hundred Foot Washes in Cambridgeshire and Norfolk

floodArea.riverOrSea: Old Bedford River, New Bedford River, Hundred Foot Drain, River Delph

items.message: River levels are starting to fall, but remain high at the Sutton Gault river gauge. We expect flooding to affect the Hundred Foot Washes, also known as the Ouse Washes. No further rainfall is forecast. We expect river levels to remain high through today, Thursday 24/02/2022. This information is correct as of 09:00 on Thursday 24 February. The causeway at Sutton Gault has approximately 7 centimetres of water on the road. There are currently no issues on the Welney or Earith causeways. Due to uneven surface of the roads, water may be deeper in places. Our incident response staff are liaising with Cambridgeshire Highways, who decide whether to close the road. Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. We are closely monitoring the situation. This message will be updated by 17:00 Thursday 24/02/22.

River levels are starting to fall, but remain high at the Sutton Gault river gauge. We expect flooding to affect the causeway at Sutton Gault. No further rainfall is forecast. We expect river levels to remain high through today, Thursday 24/02/2022. This information is correct as of 09:00 on Thursday 24 February. The causeway at Sutton Gault has approximately 7 centimetres of water on the road. Due to uneven surface of the roads, water may be deeper in places. The Environment Agency are liaising with Cambridgeshire Highways, who decide whether to close the road. This alert applies to SUTTON GAULT CAUSEWAY ONLY. Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. We are closely monitoring the situation. This message will be updated by 17:00 Thursday 24/02/22.

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels are high on the River Cherwell as a result of rainfall over the last few days. Flooding of low lying roads and farmland is expected to continue today, 24/02/2022, in the areas around Thrupp.
Further rain is forecast this morning (24/02/2022) with the potential to be heavy at times. This is forecast to clear through Thursday with drier conditions from Friday. River levels are still high but starting to stabilise in the Thrupp area and should start to fall later today. Levels will remain high over the next few days.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff will be in the area clearing trash screens. 
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 
This message will be updated this evening, 24/02/2022, or as the situation changes.

We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.description: River Aire at Allerton Ings, Barnsdale Road and Properties
items.message: River levels on the River Aire continue to fall and are below levels at which spilling into Allerton Ings occurs. As a result, levels within Allerton Ings have fallen steadily over the last 24 hours to a point where the warning is no longer in force. However, standing water may remain in the Ings. Although further unsettled weather and showers are forecast, we are not expecting any further significant rainfall and therefore we expect levels to continue to slowly fall in the next 24 hours. Please see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast.

Although further unsettled weather and showers are forecast, we are not expecting any further significant rainfall and therefore we expect levels to be able to continue to slowly fall in the next 24 hours. Please see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast.

River levels on the River Aire are falling and have now fallen below the flood risk threshold, so this warning is no longer in force. However, standing water may remain in low lying and washland areas for some time. Although further unsettled weather and showers are forecast, we are not expecting any further significant rainfall and therefore we expect levels to be able to continue to slowly fall in the next 24 hours. Please see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast.

This Flood Warning has been removed. River levels have now fallen below the property flood risk threshold. The Flood Warning for the area has now been removed.  However, a Flood Alert remains in force for the wider area, so flooding may still affect roads and low-lying land. Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours. We continue to monitor the situation. 
Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.

items.description: North Bank Road alongside the River Nene, east of Peterborough and west of Dog-in-a-Doublet Sluice
items.message: The River Nene has being falling steadily today (Wednesday, 23rd February). North Bank Road will be reopened once the Highways Authority have been able to inspect the road surface and carry out any necessary works to ensure the road is passable. There may be standing water in low lying areas and fields for several days.

River levels have continued to fall and are now below levels of concern. Levels in West Holme Washlands will not increase as levels on the Aire have dropped. There are showers forecast over the next 24 hours, but we are not expecting any further significant rainfall with dry conditions expected from Friday onwards. As a result, we expect levels to continue to fall. Please see the gov.uk website for a 5-day flood forecast.

items.description: River Aire at Hillam, Monk Fryston and Gateforth
items.message: River levels have continued to fall and are now below levels of concern. Levels in West Holme Washlands will not increase as levels on the Aire have dropped. There are showers forecast over the next 24 hours, but we are not expecting any further significant rainfall with dry conditions expected from Friday onwards. As a result, we expect levels to continue to fall. Please see the gov.uk website for a 5-day flood forecast.

River levels have continued to fall on the River Don at Fishlake and have now dropped below levels of concern, with water having stopped spilling into washlands. We have installed pumps in the area which are helping to reduce Washland levels. There are showers forecast over the next 24 hours, but we are not expecting any further significant rainfall with dry conditions expected from Friday onwards. As a result, we expect levels to continue to fall. Please see the gov.uk website for a 5-day flood forecast.

This Flood Warning has been removed as the situation is improving. 
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  The Flood Warning for the area has now been removed.  However, a Flood Alert remains in force for the wider area, so flooding may still affect roads and low lying land.  Further showers are forecast over the next 24 hours.  
We continue to monitor the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking the condition of defences and liaising with emergency services.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.

items.description: River Trent at Newark Tolney Lane and Riverside Marinas
items.message:
This Flood Warning has been removed.  
River levels are falling, but still pose a flood risk. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this warning if necessary.    
We continue to monitor the situation. Our incident response staff are patrolling watercourses in the area.  
Please see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.

items.description: River Aire at Hirst Marsh and West Marsh
items.message: River levels have continued to fall and are now below levels of concern. Levels in West Marsh Washlands will not increase as levels on the Aire have dropped. There are showers forecast over the next 24 hours, but we are not expecting any further significant rainfall with dry conditions expected from Friday onwards. As a result, we expect levels to continue to fall. Please see the gov.uk website for a 5-day flood forecast.

items.description: River Trent at Carlton on Trent including Beck Cottage
items.message:
This Flood Warning has been removed.  
River and high tide levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  The Flood Warning for the area has now been removed.  However, a Flood Alert remains in force for the wider area, so flooding may still affect roads and low-lying land.  
We continue to monitor the situation.  Our incident response staff are patrolling watercourses in the area.  
Please see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.

We continue to monitor the situation.  Our incident response staff are patrolling watercourses in the area.  
Please see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.

This Flood Warning has been removed.  
River and high tide levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  The Flood Warning for the area has now been removed.  However, a Flood Alert remains in force for the wider area, so flooding may still affect roads and low-lying land.  
We continue to monitor the situation.  Our incident response staff are patrolling watercourses in the area.  
Please see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.

A severe flood warning is in force for the River Severn at Wribbenhall, Bewdley. Severe flooding is expected to continue. There is a danger to life. 
The temporary barriers at Beales Corner exceeded their capacity on Tuesday afternoon, 22/02/22. We have withdrawn our operatives from behind the barriers. It is strongly recommended that residents evacuate from behind the defences due to the risk and take action to implement your emergency flood plan as severe flooding to homes & main roads is expected to continue. 
The level at Bewdley gauge peaked at 5.34m Wednesday morning, 23/02/22.  The level is now falling but remains high. 
We are working closely with emergency services. If you feel your life is threatened, please dial 999 for assistance. This message will be updated by 1pm on Thursday, 24/02/22, or as the situation changes.
